work.p: This manuscript, a tribute to General Philip Sheridan, is a signed, but undated, holograph poem. The unusually clean nature of this manuscript suggests that it may have been a gift copy.

titleStmt.title: Interpolation Sounds
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript is undated, but must have been composed between 1888, the year of General Sheridan's death, and 1891, the year that "Interpolation Sounds" appeared in Leaves of Grass.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Interpolation Sounds
bibl.orgName: The Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature, New York Public Library
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

lg.head: Interpolation Sounds.
lg.l: Over and through the burial chant,
Organ and solemn service, sermon, bending priests,

Of sudden battle's hurry and harsh noises—war's,
war's grim game to sight and ear in earnest;

The scout call'd up and forward—the General mounted,
and his aides around him.—the new‑brought
ward—the instantaneous order issued,

The rifle crack—the cannon thud—the rushing
forth of men from their tents,

The clank of cavalry—the strange celerity of
forming ranks—the slender bugle note,

The sound of horses' hoofs departing—saddles,
arms, accoutrements,
